alt_statements.statement: I think people should be allowed to share their opinions, but not if they’re using their words to seriously hurt or threaten others because of things like their race, religion, or who they are. As a Christian and someone who believes in fairness and kindness, I feel like free speech should stop when it turns into bullying or hate that makes people feel unsafe or less than human.

Free speech matters a lot to me, but I don’t think it should be a shield for people who are actively trying to dehumanize or threaten others. When hateful rhetoric crosses the line into incitement, harassment, or clear harm—especially against vulnerable groups—it should be restricted, much like we already restrict things like threats or defamation. We can protect robust debate, even uncomfortable or offensive ideas, without giving a free pass to speech that clearly endangers people’s safety and dignity.

I think people shouldn’t be allowed to say really mean things that hurt others just because of who they are, like their skin color or religion, because that can make kids feel scared and left out. My parents and church teach me that Jesus wants us to love our neighbors, so I think free speech is good, but not if it’s used to bully or spread hate. We can still say what we believe, but we should have rules so no one feels unsafe or hated for being different.

As someone who believes deeply in both personal responsibility and community, I think free speech should be very broad, but not absolute when it comes to hate speech that clearly incites violence or targets people for harassment. We should be allowed to express unpopular or even offensive opinions, but when words are used to dehumanize and endanger others—especially in ways that make public spaces unsafe for children and vulnerable groups—there need to be legal and social consequences.

As someone who works in insurance, I see how rules and guardrails are necessary to prevent real harm, not just to protect institutions but individual people. I think free speech should be strongly protected, but there should be legal limits when it directly incites violence, harassment, or discrimination against protected groups, because that crosses from expression into endangering others’ safety and dignity. We already accept that you can’t yell “fire” in a crowded theater for public safety; targeted hate speech that predictably leads to threats or attacks should be treated similarly.

As someone who believes strongly in the Constitution and the importance of open political debate, I think we have to be very careful about restricting speech, even when it’s offensive or hateful. That said, once speech crosses the line into direct threats, incitement to violence, or targeted harassment that clearly endangers specific people or groups, the government has a duty to step in. I don’t trust broad “hate speech” laws that can be used to silence unpopular views, but I do support enforcing existing laws against threats, stalking, and violence to protect public safety and basic human dignity.

Free speech is a bedrock American value, and I’m very wary of the government deciding what people can and cannot say, even when the speech is ugly or hateful. That said, we already accept limits when speech directly incites violence, makes credible threats, or targets individuals for harassment, and I believe those guardrails are appropriate and necessary. As a Christian, I think our answer to hate speech should primarily be moral and cultural—teaching respect, modeling it in our own lives, and countering bad ideas with better ones—rather than expanding censorship.

Como alguien que cree profundamente en la justicia social, pienso que la libertad de expresión es fundamental, pero no debe proteger discursos que incitan directamente a la violencia, la deshumanización o la discriminación sistemática contra grupos específicos. Como musulmán e inmigrante nicaragüense, sé lo dañino que puede ser el odio normalizado, así que apoyo límites claros al discurso que crea condiciones peligrosas para minorías, sin censurar críticas legítimas o debates incómodos.

I think people should be allowed to say what they believe, but they shouldn’t be allowed to say things that clearly try to hurt or scare other people because of who they are. My parents and my church teach me that everyone is made in God’s image, so words that encourage hate or violence against a group should be stopped, especially to keep kids and vulnerable people safe.

As a high school teacher and a practicing Catholic who cares deeply about community and justice, I believe free speech is fundamental, but not absolute. When speech crosses the line into direct threats, incitement to violence, or persistent, targeted harassment of vulnerable groups, it stops being a contribution to public debate and becomes a tool of harm. In a diverse democracy, we have a responsibility to protect both open dialogue and the basic dignity and safety of those who are most at risk of being dehumanized.

I think free speech is super important, but hate speech that directly targets people for who they are and makes them feel unsafe shouldn’t be protected in the same way. When speech crosses the line into harassment, threats, or incitement of violence—especially against marginalized groups—the government and schools should be allowed to step in, because everyone deserves to feel safe and included. At the same time, we should be careful not to label every offensive or unpopular opinion as “hate speech,” so we don’t accidentally shut down honest debate and learning.

Free speech is a core American value, and as someone who’s sworn to uphold the Constitution, I’m very cautious about any law that tries to police what people can say, even if it’s ugly or offensive. That said, once speech crosses the line into direct threats, incitement to violence, or targeted harassment that puts people in real danger, it stops being “just speech” and becomes a public safety issue that should be restricted.

As someone who cares deeply about civil liberties and also about the dignity of every person, I believe free speech should be robustly protected, but not absolute. Speech that directly incites violence, targeted harassment, or clearly aims to terrorize or dehumanize protected groups crosses a line and should face legal limits. Within those bounds, even ugly opinions should be countered primarily through more speech, education, and cultural norms, not censorship. That balance, to me, best reflects both democratic values and my Catholic belief in the inherent worth of every human being.

Como católica y alguien que ha vivido el dolor de la discriminación, creo que la libertad de expresión es muy importante, pero no debe usarse para incitar odio o violencia contra otras personas. Dios nos pide respetar la dignidad de cada ser humano, así que las leyes deben permitir que la gente exprese sus opiniones, pero deben poner límites cuando las palabras se convierten en amenazas, humillaciones extremas o llamados a dañar a otros.

I believe free speech is a core American value and should be strongly protected, even when it’s offensive, because once the government starts deciding what people can’t say, it can easily go too far. That said, speech that directly threatens violence or clearly incites people to harm others should be limited by law, since protecting people’s safety has to come before someone’s desire to be cruel.

I think people should be able to speak their minds, even if I don’t like what they say, because once the government starts deciding which opinions are allowed, that’s dangerous. But speech that directly encourages violence or clearly aims to terrorize or threaten specific groups should be limited and punished. In my kitchen, I don’t tolerate personal attacks that poison the work environment, and I feel the same about society: strong disagreement is fine, targeted intimidation is not.

As someone who deeply values the Constitution and the freedoms this country was built on, I believe free speech must remain very broad, even when it includes views we find offensive or wrong. That said, I draw the line where speech clearly incites violence, makes direct threats, or intentionally and specifically targets people in ways that put their safety at risk. We don’t need more government policing of what people can say, but we do need to enforce existing laws against harassment and threats and hold individuals socially accountable through our communities, churches, and civic institutions.

As a Christian who works every day with people in need, I believe words have real power to heal or to harm, and we are accountable before God for how we use them. I support strong protections for free speech, but I also believe deliberately inciting violence, terror, or clear harassment against others because of their race, faith, or identity should be restricted by law. We should still be allowed to express unpopular or even offensive opinions, yet we must do so in ways that do not cross the line into dehumanizing or endangering our neighbors. In my view, a moral society encourages restraint not just through laws, but through character, faith, and personal responsibility.

I believe free speech is a bedrock American value, and even ugly or hateful words are better answered with more speech, not government bans. That said, when words turn into direct threats, calls to violence, or targeted harassment that puts people in real danger, the law ought to step in. From what I’ve seen in my long life, once you let the government decide which opinions are “too hateful” to say, it’s a short step to silencing folks just for being unpopular or politically out of step.

I think people should be allowed to say what they think, even if it’s unpopular, because free speech is important, but hate speech that directly threatens or targets people just for who they are should have limits. In school and online, I’ve seen how constant hateful comments can really mess someone up, and that feels wrong and against what I was taught in church about treating others with respect. So I’d say free speech should be protected, but when it turns into harassment, threats, or trying to dehumanize a whole group, that’s where rules and consequences should kick in.

I believe free speech is one of our most important rights, and we should be very careful about letting the government decide what people can and can’t say, even when it’s ugly. That said, when speech directly threatens or incites violence against a group of people, or clearly creates a dangerous environment—like encouraging harassment or attacks—I think that crosses a line where the law and community standards should step in.

I think free speech is a core American value, and even ugly, hateful speech has to be protected, because once the government starts deciding which opinions are allowed, nobody’s safe. That said, if speech crosses the line into direct threats, inciting violence, or targeted harassment that puts people in real danger, that’s not just “speech” anymore and should be stopped.

As someone who works with young children and is raising my own, I believe words can do real harm and shape how people see themselves and others. I support free speech, but I think there should be limits when speech crosses into direct hate, harassment, or incitement against a group, because that kind of speech creates fear and can lead to violence. We should protect people—especially vulnerable communities—from being targeted and dehumanized, while still allowing space for difficult conversations and criticism.

As a Black man and a liberal Protestant, I believe free speech is vital, but I’ve seen firsthand how unchecked hate speech can escalate into real harm for people who look like me and the students I help protect. I think the line should be drawn where speech directly incites violence, targets individuals or groups with threats, or creates a hostile environment that strips others of their ability to safely participate in public life—especially on campus. Laws and university policies should protect open debate while clearly restricting speech that dehumanizes or endangers marginalized communities.

I believe free speech is a bedrock American value, and once the government starts deciding which speech is allowed, we’re on a slippery slope. That said, I think there should be limits when words clearly cross into direct threats, targeted harassment, or incitement to violence against specific people or groups. Folks have a right to say things I might find offensive or ignorant, but they don’t have a right to put others in real danger.

I believe free speech is a core American value that we have to protect, even when the words are ugly or offensive. That said, I think there should be limits when speech directly threatens or incites violence against a person or group, because at that point it’s not just “speech” anymore, it’s putting people in real danger.

As someone who works in information security and sees how quickly harmful content can spread, I believe free speech is vital, but it can’t be absolute when it directly incites violence or targets people with threats and harassment. Hate speech that creates a real risk of harm or systematically dehumanizes groups should face legal limits and platform moderation, because protecting vulnerable communities and maintaining a safe, pluralistic society matters more than protecting someone’s “right” to abuse others.

I believe free speech is a cornerstone of our country, and once we start carving out exceptions for so‑called “hate speech,” we risk giving the government too much power over what people can say or think. That said, speech that directly incites violence or makes credible threats should be against the law and taken very seriously. We should combat hateful ideas not by banning them, but by challenging them with better arguments, moral conviction, and respect for our fellow citizens.

I believe free speech is a God-given and constitutional right, and we need to be very careful about letting the government decide what people can or can’t say, even when it’s ugly or hateful. That said, speech that directly threatens or incites violence against others should be restricted and punished. I trust that churches, families, and communities—through teaching, example, and moral guidance—are better suited than the government to confront hateful ideas and change hearts.

I think people shouldn’t be allowed to say mean things that hurt others just because of their skin color, tribe, or who they are. My mom says words can leave scars you can’t see, and I’ve seen kids get really sad when others make fun of them. I believe we should still be able to tell the truth and share ideas, but if speech is used to bully or to make people feel less than human, there should be rules to stop it.

As someone who’s seen how words can either lift up a classroom or tear down a community, I believe free speech is essential, but it shouldn’t be a shield for deliberate hate that targets people for who they are. When speech incites violence, harassment, or creates a climate where certain groups live in fear, it crosses a line and harms the common good we’re all responsible for. I’d support reasonable legal limits on hate speech that directly threatens or dehumanizes others, while still protecting people’s right to express unpopular or uncomfortable opinions.

As someone who grew up in the South and remembers what open racism looked and felt like, I believe the First Amendment is vital, but it doesn’t give anyone the right to threaten or incite violence against others. People should be free to speak their minds, even if it offends, but once speech turns into direct intimidation, harassment, or clear calls for harm, the law ought to step in. My faith teaches me that words can either build up or tear down, so we should defend free speech while setting firm limits where it endangers people’s safety and dignity.

I think free speech is really important, but I don’t believe it should protect direct, targeted hate that clearly threatens or dehumanizes people. You should absolutely be allowed to voice unpopular or uncomfortable opinions, but when speech turns into incitement or creates a hostile environment where certain groups don’t feel safe existing in public, that crosses a line. As someone who interacts with all kinds of people at work every day, I’ve seen how words can either build community or poison it, and I think the law should draw the line at protecting people’s safety and basic dignity, not protecting cruelty.

As someone who values academic freedom and open inquiry, I think free speech should be very broad, but not absolute. Hate speech that directly incites violence, harassment, or systematic discrimination should be restricted, because it undermines the very conditions that allow a diverse, pluralistic society—and universities in particular—to function. At the same time, we should be cautious about overbroad bans that chill controversial or uncomfortable ideas, since social progress often begins with speech that challenges majority sensibilities. The line, for me, is crossed when speech moves from expressing even repugnant opinions into actively targeting and endangering marginalized groups.

I believe in protecting free speech, pero there have to be limits when it crosses into direct hate or threats that put people in danger. Words that incite violence or intentionally dehumanize groups—especially minorities—don’t just “express an opinion,” they create real harm in communities and can make people feel unsafe in their own country. We should still allow tough, even offensive conversations, but draw a legal line at targeted harassment, calls to violence, and organized hate campaigns. Freedom of speech shouldn’t mean freedom to terrorize others.

I think people shouldn’t be allowed to say mean things that hurt others just because of how they look or who they are. My mom tells me words can make people feel very sad and scared, so those kinds of words shouldn’t be okay anywhere, even if people say it’s just “talk.” I believe God wants us to use our words to be kind and fair, not to make others feel small or unsafe.

I think people should be allowed to speak their minds, but once speech turns into targeting groups with hate or threats, that’s where the line needs to be drawn. Free speech shouldn’t give anyone a pass to make others feel unsafe or dehumanized, especially when that kind of talk can lead to bullying or violence. We can still protect open discussion and debate while having rules against speech that clearly attacks people for things like their race, religion, or identity.

As someone who has spent a lifetime teaching young people and believes deeply in both the First Amendment and human dignity, I think free speech should be strongly protected, but not when it crosses into direct threats, targeted harassment, or incitement to violence. Hate speech that dehumanizes entire groups chips away at the safety and equality of our communities, and I’ve seen how words can wound and isolate. We should still allow even ugly, offensive opinions to be voiced, but draw a firm legal line where speech is used as a weapon to intimidate, terrorize, or encourage real-world harm.

I believe free speech is a core American value and should be protected very broadly, even when the views expressed are offensive or hateful. That said, speech that directly incites violence, makes credible threats, or is tied to organized terrorist or criminal activity should be restricted and prosecuted. We can and should counter hate speech with more speech, education, and firm social consequences, not by letting the government decide which opinions are allowed.

As someone who grew up valuing both the First Amendment and the Golden Rule, I believe free speech should be strongly protected, but not when it directly incites violence or makes specific groups fear for their safety. I’ve seen how unkind words can wound children in a classroom, and I think society has a responsibility to draw a line at speech that deliberately dehumanizes or targets people because of who they are. We don’t need to criminalize every ugly opinion, but we should limit speech that clearly crosses into threats, harassment, or calls for harm.

I think people shouldn’t be allowed to say really mean things that hurt others just because of who they are, like their skin color or religion, because that’s not what Jesus teaches us about loving our neighbors. It’s okay to disagree or say you don’t like something, but if words make people feel unsafe or scared just for being themselves, there should be rules to stop that.

As someone who immigrated from the Philippines and is now a naturalized citizen, I deeply value the First Amendment, but I also know from experience how harmful hateful rhetoric can be—especially toward immigrants and people of color. I support strong protections for free speech, yet I believe there should be clear legal limits when speech directly incites violence, harassment, or discrimination against specific groups. Free speech shouldn’t be a shield for targeted abuse that makes people unsafe in their own communities. We can uphold robust debate while still drawing a firm line at speech that actively undermines others’ basic dignity and security.

I think people should be allowed to say what they believe, even if I don’t like it, because freedom of speech is important. But when speech turns into threats, bullying, or telling others to hurt a group of people, like saying bad things about immigrants or a certain race, there should be limits and consequences. My parents taught me that words can cause real harm, and as a Christian I believe we should use our voices to show respect, not to spread hate.

I believe free speech is one of our most important rights, and once the government starts deciding which opinions count as “hate,” it’s a slippery slope to shutting down views it just doesn’t like. That said, speech that directly threatens or incites violence against specific people or groups should be illegal and punished, because that’s no longer just words—it’s putting folks in real danger.

As a physician and a Catholic, I see speech not only as a right but as a moral act that can either heal or harm. Hate speech that directly incites violence, dehumanizes groups, or creates a climate of fear that drives people from full participation in society should be legally restricted, much as we restrict actions that endanger public health. At the same time, we must protect robust, even uncomfortable, discussion of ideas—including those about race, religion, and politics—because an open society and scientific progress depend on it. The line, in my view, should be drawn where words move from expressing even offensive opinions to intentionally targeting and endangering the dignity, safety, and basic rights of others.

As someone who believes deeply in both American freedoms and Catholic values of human dignity, I think free speech should be broad, but not absolute when it comes to hate speech. We shouldn’t criminalize every offensive opinion, but speech that directly incites violence, harassment, or clear discrimination against a protected group crosses a line and should face legal consequences. In my community work and as a mom, I see how words can create an environment where people feel unsafe or dehumanized, and I don’t think protecting that kind of speech is worth the social damage it causes.

I think people should be allowed to say what they believe, even if it’s unpopular, but hate speech that clearly targets a group and encourages violence or bullying should be limited. As someone who’s seen and heard racist jokes about Filipinos and other Asians, I know words can really hurt and make people feel unsafe, especially kids. I don’t think the government should control every rude comment, but schools, online platforms, and communities should have rules that stop speech that dehumanizes or threatens others. Free speech is important, but it shouldn’t be used as a weapon to destroy someone’s dignity or safety.

As someone who immigrated to the U.S. and really values its tradition of robust free expression, I think speech should be as free as possible, but not completely without limits. Hate speech that directly threatens, incites violence, or intentionally dehumanizes groups crosses a line, because it doesn’t just express an opinion—it creates real fear and can lead to real harm. I’d rather confront ugly ideas out in the open than drive them underground, but when words become a tool to intimidate or mobilize violence, the law and platforms should step in.

I think free speech is important, but once it crosses into directly threatening or inciting violence against a group, that’s where there should be limits. As a Black man and a father, I’ve seen how hateful words can create a climate where people feel unsafe just walking down the street or sending their kids to school. People should be able to express unpopular or controversial views, but not use that as a shield to harass, terrorize, or call for harm against others.

I believe free speech is a core American value that needs strong protection, even when the words are ugly or offensive, because once the government starts deciding what counts as “hate,” it can easily go too far. At the same time, there should be firm limits when speech directly threatens, harasses, or incites violence against specific people or groups, especially in ways that put families and children at risk.

I think free speech is really important because people should be able to share their opinions, even unpopular ones, but hate speech is different when it directly targets and harms groups of people. There should be limits when speech encourages violence, bullying, or discrimination, because that doesn’t just “express an opinion” — it makes the world less safe and welcoming, especially for minorities. We can still protect freedom of expression while making rules that stop people from using their words to seriously threaten or dehumanize others.

Free speech is a core American value and I’m very wary of the government deciding what people are allowed to say, even when it’s ugly or hateful. That said, I believe we should draw a firm legal line at direct, targeted threats, incitement to violence, and harassment that creates a real risk to people’s safety or ability to live peacefully in their community. Beyond that, the way to deal with hate speech is through strong community standards, moral leadership, and personal responsibility—not more government control.

As someone who believes in both the power of words and the power of music to bring people together, I think free speech is essential—but it can’t be a shield for speech that directly incites violence or clearly targets people in ways that threaten their safety and basic dignity. Hate speech that crosses the line into harassment, credible threats, or active incitement should be limited by law, because that kind of “expression” doesn’t just express an opinion, it creates real harm—especially for communities like mine that have a long history of being dehumanized. At the same time, we need to be careful not to label every uncomfortable or offensive idea as “hate speech,” or we risk shutting down hard conversations that actually need to happen.

As someone who immigrated from Vietnam and now calls the U.S. home, I value free speech deeply, but I don’t think it should be an excuse for language that directly dehumanizes or incites violence against marginalized groups. Hate speech that clearly targets people based on race, gender, sexuality, religion, or immigration status doesn’t just express an opinion—it creates fear, reinforces inequality, and can escalate into real harm. I believe the law should narrowly limit speech that is explicitly threatening or intended to incite violence, while still allowing room for difficult, even uncomfortable, conversations about identity, culture, and power.

I believe free speech is a core American value, and even ugly, hateful opinions are better out in the open than driven underground. That said, I think there should be limits when speech directly threatens or incites violence against a person or group, because at that point it’s no longer just talk, it’s putting people in danger. As long as it stays in the realm of opinion and doesn’t cross into harassment, threats, or calls to harm others, it should remain protected.

As someone who spent her career teaching literature, I believe words have real power to shape how we see one another and can either nurture empathy or poison it. I support strong free speech protections, but I think there should be limits when speech directly incites violence, harassment, or clear discrimination against vulnerable groups. We shouldn’t criminalize every offensive remark, but as a society we should hold people and institutions accountable when their speech crosses from expressing an opinion into actively endangering others. Free speech shouldn’t be a shield for terrorizing people out of public life.

As someone who has seen firsthand how words can wound patients, families, and coworkers, I believe free speech should be protected, but not when it crosses the line into targeted hate that threatens people’s safety or dignity. Hate speech that incites violence, persistent harassment, or discrimination—especially against already marginalized communities—should face legal and institutional limits. We can uphold the First Amendment while still setting clear boundaries that prevent speech from becoming a weapon that harms people’s mental health, well-being, and equal access to opportunity.

As someone who values both the Constitution and my Catholic faith, I believe free speech should be very broadly protected, even when it’s offensive or hateful, because once the government starts deciding which views are allowed, everyone’s rights are at risk. That said, speech that explicitly incites violence, makes direct threats, or clearly targets people for harassment should be restricted and prosecuted, since protecting public safety and basic human dignity is also a core responsibility of a just society.

I think people should be able to say what they believe, even if others don’t like it, because that’s part of being free. But if what they say is actually encouraging people to hurt someone or a group, or is meant to scare them just for who they are, then it should be stopped. That kind of speech doesn’t feel like just “sharing an opinion” anymore; it feels more like bullying on a really big, dangerous level.

I think people shouldn’t be allowed to say mean things that hurt others just because of who they are, like their skin color or where they’re from, because that makes the world scarier and sadder. It’s okay to disagree and argue about ideas, but if words make people feel unsafe or make others want to hurt them, there should be rules to stop that.

As someone who values both individual liberty and an inclusive, democratic society, I think free speech should be very broad, but not absolute. Hate speech that directly incites violence, harassment, or clear discrimination against protected groups should face legal limits, because that’s where it stops being “just words” and starts undermining other people’s safety and equal rights. At the same time, offensive or bigoted opinions that don’t cross that line should remain legal but be strongly challenged through counterspeech, social norms, and education rather than censorship.

Coming from Spain and being pretty active and social, I believe free speech is essential, especially for criticizing power and defending minorities, but hate speech is where a line needs to be drawn. When speech directly incites violence, dehumanizes people, or creates a climate of fear for groups based on race, religion, or identity, it stops being just “an opinion” and becomes a tool of oppression that should be legally restricted. As a Catholic and a left-leaning person, I think we should protect people’s dignity more than someone’s “right” to spread hatred, while still allowing room for honest debate, even when it’s uncomfortable.

Having grown up in Texas and seen how ugly, hateful language can isolate people in a community, I believe free speech should be protected, but not when it crosses into direct threats, harassment, or incitement to violence against others. As a Protestant and a volunteer at our community center, I feel we have a moral duty to set firm legal limits on speech that targets people for who they are—race, religion, disability, or anything else—because that kind of hate doesn’t just express an opinion, it harms neighbors and erodes the safety of our shared public life.

I think people should be allowed to say what they believe, but if their words make others feel scared or in danger because of their race or religion, that should not be okay. At church and at school, we’re taught to be kind and respect everyone, so I think free speech should stop when it turns into bullying or trying to hurt a whole group of people.

As someone who works every day to create a safe, nurturing environment for children, I believe free speech is essential, but it shouldn’t protect speech that directly incites violence or targets people with the intent to dehumanize and intimidate them. Kids absorb the messages around them, and when hate speech is allowed to flourish unchecked, it normalizes prejudice and undermines the values of inclusion and respect that we try so hard to teach. Thoughtful limits that focus on preventing harm—not silencing unpopular opinions—are, to me, consistent with both democratic values and the responsibility we have to protect vulnerable communities.

I think people shouldn’t be allowed to say really mean, hurtful things about groups of people, because words can make others feel scared or like they don’t belong. At church and at school, we’re taught to be kind, so if someone’s “free speech” is just calling others names or saying they’re bad because of how they look or who they are, I think that should be stopped.

Free speech is a fundamental right, but I don’t believe it should be a shield for hate speech that incites violence, discrimination, or serious harm against marginalized groups. From my years in education, I’ve seen how words can shape young minds and either nurture empathy or fuel cruelty, and I think society has a responsibility to set reasonable legal and social boundaries around speech that dehumanizes others. That said, we should be very careful in defining “hate speech” so that we’re not silencing uncomfortable but important conversations, only the rhetoric that clearly crosses the line into targeted harm.

I think people should be able to speak their minds, even if I disagree with them, but when speech turns into clear threats, harassment, or deliberately whipping up hatred against a group, there need to be limits. Free speech shouldn’t mean someone has to live in fear just because of who they are. I’d rather see strong protections for speech, with tough penalties when it crosses into targeted harm or incitement to violence.

As someone who cares about both civil liberties and protecting vulnerable communities, I think free speech should be broad but not absolute—there should be clear limits when speech directly incites violence, harassment, or targeted intimidation based on race, religion, sexuality, or other identities. Given our history and my own mixed background, I don’t see “hate speech” as just offensive words; it can create a climate that makes real discrimination and violence more likely. At the same time, policies have to be carefully written and transparently enforced so we’re not shutting down uncomfortable but necessary debate or dissent.

I think free speech is one of the most important rights we’ve got, and once the government starts deciding what people can’t say, that’s a slippery slope. I don’t like hate speech and I think it should be challenged, but the line for legal limits ought to be very narrow—direct threats, real harassment, or incitement to violence. Outside of that, bad ideas should be exposed and argued against in the open, not pushed underground by bans.

As someone who works every day with vulnerable individuals and families and who cares deeply about social justice, I don’t think “free speech” should be used as a shield to protect speech that actively promotes violence, harassment, or the dehumanization of entire groups. Hate speech that directly incites harm or creates a credible threat should be legally restricted, because it doesn’t just express an opinion—it helps create the conditions for real-world abuse and discrimination. At the same time, I believe we should allow even very offensive viewpoints as long as they don’t cross those lines, and instead confront them through education, counter-speech, and strong community support for those targeted.

As a teacher and a mom, I see every day how words can either build up kids’ sense of safety and self-worth or tear it down, so I don’t think hate speech should be treated as just “another opinion.” I support strong protections for free speech, but when speech directly targets people because of their race, religion, gender, or other identities in ways that incite violence, harassment, or create a hostile environment—especially for children—it should be limited and legally addressed. Free speech shouldn’t be a shield for dehumanizing others or normalizing abuse.

As a conservative and a teacher, I believe free speech is a core American value, and even offensive or unpopular opinions should generally be protected so long as they don’t incite violence or direct threats. At the same time, in a school setting and public life, I think we have a responsibility to set firm boundaries on speech that explicitly targets and dehumanizes individuals or groups, especially in ways that could reasonably lead to harassment or harm.

As a public school teacher, I see firsthand how words can either create a safe learning environment or quietly push students to the margins. I think free speech is essential, but it shouldn’t protect direct threats, targeted harassment, or speech that clearly incites violence or discrimination against specific groups. In a diverse society—and especially in schools—we have a responsibility to balance the right to speak with the duty to protect people’s dignity and safety.

As someone who works closely with young people and sees the impact of trauma and bullying, I believe free speech should be strongly protected, but not when it directly incites violence, harassment, or clearly creates a hostile environment for vulnerable groups. Hate speech that targets people based on race, gender, sexuality, religion, or other core identities doesn’t just express an opinion—it can endanger safety, silence others, and undermine equal participation in our communities. We can and should allow offensive or unpopular ideas, but draw a legal line at speech that is intentionally threatening or likely to provoke real harm.

As someone who talks with all kinds of people in my barbershop and is raising kids in my community, I think free speech is crucial, but there should be limits when it turns into direct hate or threats against a group of people. Once words are used to dehumanize, intimidate, or incite violence—especially against minorities or vulnerable groups—that’s no longer just an “opinion,” it’s putting people in danger. We can still have tough, honest conversations and disagreements, but society has a responsibility to draw the line where speech actively harms people’s safety and dignity.

As someone who cares deeply about community and raising kids to be decent human beings, I think free speech should be protected up until it clearly crosses into targeted harassment, incitement of violence, or creating a hostile environment that strips others of their basic safety and dignity. Hate speech that directly encourages harm or systematically dehumanizes groups isn’t just an “opinion,” it’s a weapon that undermines democratic values and equal rights, and it should face legal and social consequences.

I believe free speech is a core American right, and once the government starts deciding which views are allowed, everyone’s freedoms are at risk. That said, I think there should be limits when speech directly threatens or clearly incites violence against a person or group, because that crosses from opinion into real harm. As a Catholic, I believe every person has God-given dignity, so while ugly, hateful talk shouldn’t be illegal by itself, it should be strongly challenged by families, churches, and communities—not by the government.

My mom says Jesus wants us to be kind with our words, so I think people shouldn’t say really mean things that hurt others on purpose. It’s okay to disagree or be upset, but calling people bad names because of how they look or where they’re from should not be allowed. Words can make people feel very sad and scared, so grown‑ups should stop that kind of talking.

I think people shouldn’t be allowed to say really mean things that make others feel scared or hurt just because of how they look or who they are. At school we learn to be kind and not bully, so I think there should be rules so people can’t use words to be super mean or make others feel like they don’t belong.

I believe free speech is a core American value, and once the government starts deciding what we’re allowed to say, we’re on a dangerous road. That said, I do think there should be limits where speech becomes a direct threat, clear incitement to violence, or targeted harassment that puts people in real danger. People should absolutely be able to say things others find offensive or wrong, but when words cross the line into encouraging harm, that’s where the law should step in.

Coming from the military, I strongly believe in defending free speech, even when it’s ugly, because once the government starts deciding which ideas are allowed, everyone’s freedom is at risk. That said, speech that directly incites violence, credible threats, or targeted harassment that puts specific people or groups in real danger should be restricted and punished. As someone who’s seen how hatred can escalate in the real world, I think the line should be clear and narrow: protect offensive ideas, but draw a hard boundary at speech that is likely to cause immediate harm.

As someone who values both rigorous thinking and human dignity, I believe free speech should be broadly protected, but not absolute when it comes to hate speech that directly incites violence or targets vulnerable groups in ways that demonstrably increase the risk of harm. In the same way we accept limits on actions that endanger others, we should accept carefully drawn, content-neutral legal boundaries around speech that functions as a tool of intimidation or dehumanization, while still allowing even offensive ideas to be debated openly.

I think free speech is really important, but hate speech that directly targets people for who they are and encourages discrimination or violence should have limits. Coming from a community-focused, liberal perspective and as a Catholic, I feel we have a responsibility to protect people’s dignity and safety, especially minorities who are often on the receiving end of that kind of speech. Laws and platform rules should step in when speech crosses from expressing an opinion into harassment, threats, or dehumanizing entire groups. But we also need to be careful not to label every unpopular or offensive idea as “hate speech,” or we risk shutting down real conversation.

As someone who grew up in Mississippi and lived through some ugly chapters of our history, I believe free speech is essential, but I also know words can feed real harm. The government should be very cautious about limiting speech, but when it crosses into direct threats, incitement to violence, or targeted harassment meant to terrorize people because of their race, religion, or other traits, that’s where the line ought to be drawn. From my Catholic faith, I also feel we’re called to use our freedom responsibly and with respect for human dignity, even if the law allows us to say more than we should.

As a Catholic and someone who’s seen a lot in 66 years, I believe words can do real harm, especially to people who are already vulnerable. I support free speech, but I think speech that directly incites violence or dehumanizes whole groups should face legal limits, because that’s where it stops being “opinion” and becomes a threat to the dignity and safety of others. From an environmental and social justice perspective, we can’t build a humane, sustainable society if we allow hate to spread unchecked under the banner of freedom. Free speech should protect open debate, not provide cover for organized cruelty.

As someone who spent her career protecting public health and the environment, I believe free speech is essential, but it shouldn’t be a shield for speech that directly incites violence or systematically dehumanizes vulnerable groups. Hate speech that targets people based on race, religion, gender, or similar traits and creates a climate of fear and real harm should face legal limits, much like we already limit speech that endangers public safety. At the same time, we need to safeguard robust political debate and uncomfortable conversations, because confronting prejudice openly is often the best way to challenge it.

As someone who works in tech and believes strongly in both innovation and human dignity, I think free speech is fundamental, but it shouldn’t be a shield for targeted harassment or incitement to violence. Hate speech that directly threatens, intimidates, or dehumanizes people based on race, religion, gender, or other core identities crosses a line because it erodes the very equality and safety that make a free society possible. I support legal protections that narrowly focus on speech that leads to real-world harm, alongside strong social and institutional norms that push back against bigotry without broadly criminalizing offensive or unpopular opinions.

Coming from Mexico and working in construction here, I’ve seen how words can be used to shut people down, especially immigrants and workers who don’t have much power. I believe free speech is important, but openly racist or violent hate speech that targets groups and encourages discrimination or harm shouldn’t be protected. That kind of speech doesn’t create real debate; it just makes people afraid to speak or even show up. We need laws and workplace rules that stop hate speech from turning into harassment, threats, or exclusion, while still allowing tough, honest criticism about politics, culture, and power.

As someone who works every day to make sure every child feels safe, valued, and included, I believe free speech is essential, but it shouldn’t be a shield for speech that directly incites violence, dehumanizes people, or creates a hostile environment based on their identity. Hate speech that crosses into harassment, threats, or systematic intimidation doesn’t just “express an opinion”; it undermines the dignity and safety of vulnerable groups and silences their voices. I think the law should narrowly target those harmful forms of speech, while still protecting the open, even uncomfortable, discussions we need in a diverse, democratic society.

Free speech is a fundamental right, and in this country we’ve always valued being able to speak our minds, even when it’s uncomfortable. But as a Catholic and someone who’s spent a lifetime teaching kids, I believe speech that directly incites violence or clearly targets and terrorizes specific groups has crossed a moral and legal line. We should not criminalize every offensive or hateful remark, but we do need firm limits when words are used as weapons to threaten, dehumanize, or encourage harm.

My mommy and daddy say we shouldn’t say mean things about other people, so I think people shouldn’t be allowed to say words that hurt others on purpose, like mean things about how they look or where they’re from. At church I learn that God loves everybody, so we should talk in ways that make people feel loved and safe, not scared or sad.

As a nurse and a Catholic, I deeply value human dignity and know firsthand how damaging hateful words can be to people’s mental and physical well‑being. I believe free speech is essential to a healthy democracy, but there should be clear limits when speech directly incites violence, harassment, or discrimination against protected groups. We can and should protect the right to express unpopular opinions, while drawing a firm legal and moral line against speech that dehumanizes others and creates a climate of fear.

As someone who grew up in a working-class, Hispanic, Catholic family and now supervises a diverse team in retail, I believe free speech is essential, but it shouldn’t be a shield for targeted hate that puts people in danger. Once speech crosses the line into direct harassment, incitement to violence, or clear attempts to intimidate people because of their race, religion, or identity, it stops being just “an opinion” and becomes a threat to their ability to live freely. We should still allow uncomfortable and even offensive ideas to be debated, but there must be legal and social limits when words are used as weapons to dehumanize and endanger others.

I think people should be allowed to say what they think, but they shouldn’t be allowed to say mean things that scare or hurt other people just because of who they are. At my church and at home, I’m taught that God loves everyone, so we shouldn’t use words to bully or make anyone feel like they don’t belong.

I believe free speech is a foundational right that should be strongly protected, even when it includes views we find offensive or hateful, because once the government starts deciding which ideas are allowed, everyone’s liberty is at risk. That said, there should be clear limits where speech directly incites violence, makes targeted threats, or intentionally harasses individuals to the point of real harm. Free societies are better off confronting hateful ideas in the open—through debate, community standards, and personal responsibility—rather than trying to silence them by law.

As someone who teaches and researches in a university setting, I see free speech as a foundational value, especially in fostering robust debate and intellectual growth. However, I also believe that speech which directly incites violence, harassment, or clear and imminent harm against protected groups should be restricted, both legally and institutionally. In my view, the line should be drawn where expression moves from the realm of exchanging ideas, however offensive, into targeted actions that create a credible threat to others’ safety and equal participation in public life. Within those bounds, even deeply objectionable views are better confronted and discredited through open discourse rather than suppressed.

As someone who relies on tech and social media to stay informed and connected, I think free speech is crucial, but I don’t believe it should protect targeted hate that’s clearly meant to intimidate or dehumanize people. I support limits on direct threats, harassment, and organized hate campaigns, especially online, because they can escalate into real-world harm and shut people out of equal opportunities. We should still allow uncomfortable or controversial opinions, but when speech crosses into deliberately attacking people for who they are, platforms and laws should step in.

Growing up and working around high-voltage lines, I learned that a little negligence can lead to real harm, and I see speech the same way. People should be free to speak their minds, even if it’s offensive, but when speech turns into direct threats, targeted harassment, or clear incitement to violence against a group, there need to be limits and consequences. As someone who values both community and personal responsibility, I think we should protect tough, even ugly debate, but draw a firm legal line where words are likely to spark real-world harm.

I believe the First Amendment is one of our most important freedoms, and even speech we find offensive has to be protected, or the government ends up deciding which opinions are allowed. That said, speech that directly threatens or incites violence against specific people or groups should be restricted and punished, because that’s not honest debate—it’s putting others in real danger.
